word.entryDescription: something you say to greet somebody in the evening
word.entryExample: Good evening, Mark. Nice to see you.

word.entryDescription: making you healthy and well
word.entryExample: Fruit and vegetables are good for you.

word.entryDescription: something you say to greet somebody in the morning
word.entryExample: Good morning, class!

word.entryDescription: someone who is lazy and never does anything useful
word.entryExample: She looks a lot happier since she left that good-for-nothing husband of hers.

word.entryDescription: describes someone who is physically attractive
word.entryExample: Do you think George Clooney is good-looking?

word.entryDescription: something you say to somebody when you are leaving
word.entryExample: Goodbye, Mr Brown!

word.entryDescription: information that is passed from one person to another about the personal matters of other people, often unkind or not known for certain
word.entryExample: What's new? Got any gossip?

word.entryDescription: to talk about the personal matters of other people, often saying things that are unkind or not known for certain
word.entryExample: Are you going to spend all day gossiping about Rachel or are you going to do some work?

word.entryDescription: the group of people who control a country politically
word.entryExample: Athens has a reputation as being the cradle of democratic governments.

word.entryDescription: a doctor who provides general medical help for people living in a particular area
word.entryExample: Your GP will refer you to a specialist.

word.entryDescription: a system which shows your position and gives you directions using signals from satellites
word.entryExample: Many of these cameras now have wifi and GPS so that you can share your photos with your friends and the camera tags where you took the picture.

word.entryDescription: a smooth and beautiful way of moving
word.entryExample: Miko celebrate the traditional role of a Japanese woman with grace, poise and elegance.

word.entryDescription: smooth and attractive in shape or movement
word.entryExample: A long neck makes a person look graceful and a thick neck makes a person look strong.

word.entryDescription: a number or letter which shows how good or bad your work is; a mark
word.entryExample: I think I'll get a good grade.

word.entryDescription: in a way which is slow and takes a long time
word.entryExample: Primary forests are gradually cut down and replaced by pastures.

word.entryDescription: relating to a person who has received an academic degree or diploma
word.entryExample: Laura is a graduate student.

word.entryDescription: somebody who has obtained a first degree from college or university
word.entryExample: Sixth formers and students can apply as well as school leavers and graduates.

word.entryDescription: to complete a first degree course successfully
word.entryExample: I've just graduated from college.

word.entryDescription: the fact of receiving a degree after finishing studies at a college or university
word.entryExample: She worked as a teacher after graduation.

word.entryDescription: images or words drawn on walls in public places
word.entryExample: Ann was commissioned to draw a graffiti on the school courtyard walls.

word.entryDescription: small hard seeds from a cereal plant such as wheat, rice, barley, etc
word.entryExample: You should eat dairy, protein, grains, fats, fruit and vegetables.

word.entryDescription: the rules by which words change their form and go together to form phrases and sentences
word.entryExample: William wants to learn Spanish because the grammar is easy and he enjoys speaking it in the summer.

word.entryDescription: plural of 'grandchild' – a child of your son or daughter
word.entryExample: She has four grandchildren.

word.entryDescription: the daughter of your son or daughter
word.entryExample: My granddaughter is two years old.

word.entryDescription: the father of your mother or father
word.entryExample: My grandfather lives on a farm.

word.entryDescription: an informal word for 'grandmother'
word.entryExample: Grandma lives in London.

word.entryDescription: the mother of your mother or father
word.entryExample: My grandmother has grey hair and wears glasses.

word.entryDescription: an informal word for 'grandfather'
word.entryExample: Grandpa is taking us to the zoo!

word.entryDescription: the parent of your mother or father
word.entryExample: I visit my grandparents during summer holiday.

word.entryDescription: the son of your son or daughter
word.entryExample: He's taking his grandson to the park.

word.entryDescription: a small round green or purple fruit which grows in bunches on a small tree
word.entryExample: There are some purple grapes or some green grapes.

word.entryDescription: a low plant with lots of thin green leaves that grows in a garden, park or field
word.entryExample: Cows eat a lot of grass.

word.entryDescription: a large area of land where wild grass grows
word.entryExample: Grasslands occur naturally on all continents except Antarctica.

word.entryDescription: to cut food into small thin pieces by rubbing it against a grater
word.entryExample: Have you seen the grater? I need to grate some cheese.

word.entryDescription: to snack, eating small amounts of food often, instead of eating full meals
word.entryExample: In many homes, people graze their way through the day, snacking on crisps or chocolate in front of the TV or on the go.

word.entryDescription: very good
word.entryExample: What a great story!

word.entryDescription: something that is green is the colour of grass
word.entryExample: The walls in my room are green.

word.entryDescription: energy obtained from renewable sources such as water, wind or sun
word.entryExample: Matt is setting up a company producing green energy from wave power.

word.entryDescription: referring to land that hasn't been built on
word.entryExample: They say that their housing density plan takes up less greenfield land than previously.

word.entryDescription: a building made of glass or plastic which gives warmth and protection to plants being grown inside
word.entryExample: It's warmer in the greenhouse, so tomatoes grow easily there.

word.entryDescription: something that is grey is the colour of dark clouds
word.entryExample: Elephants are grey.

word.entryDescription: to cook above or under direct heat
word.entryExample: Should I grill the steak or better fry it?

word.entryDescription: cooked above or under direct heat
word.entryExample: What does Kate's dad want for the grilled mushrooms?

word.entryDescription: to break something into very small pieces by pressing something down on it and moving it around
word.entryExample: To get the perfect cup of coffee you need to grind your own beans.

word.entryDescription: to hold something tightly, or to quickly take hold of something; to clutch; to grasp
word.entryExample: That film was scary – Jessica kept gripping my arm the whole way through.

word.entryDescription: extremely interesting and exciting and completely holding you attention
word.entryExample: I think the plot was really fabulous, more gripping than Toy Story 1.

word.entryDescription: a small shop where you can buy food and household items
word.entryExample: You can get some bread and milk at the grocery store.

word.entryDescription: making yourself clean and tidy
word.entryExample: Actually, I only spend about 30 minutes a day grooming.

word.entryDescription: the part of the surface of the earth that you walk on
word.entryExample: You mustn't sit on the ground.

word.entryDescription: the floor of a building at or nearest ground level
word.entryExample: The kitchen is on the ground floor of my house.
